segments.text: for Mrs. Kimball's cultural geography class.
I'm interviewing Sam Lampo in Bryan College Station.
This is Sam J. Lampo.
I live at 601 Gordon Street.
And I live with my son-in-law since my wife passed away.
And I was born in 1900.
And when I was two years old, we moved to a location on Dilley-Chartef.
My father bought the land, bought 107 acres of land and paid $10 an acre.
We struggled to pay for it, but in about three years, we got it paid for.
And from then on, of course, I went to part-time school, stayed with my parents.
and if I could, when I'd go to school.
We went to an old country school, which we used to call Mount Prayer.
Well, my land was transferred to another school, which was Prospect.
And the reason it was transferred was, we were going to Prospect, but Mount Prayer before was because there was a big creek, and every time it would rain,
Well, I had to spend the night with somebody because I couldn't get home on account of high waters.
So anyway, they transferred our land back to Prospect and went there until I was about 17 years old.
In fact, I went up to the seventh grade.
Went to Dallas, stayed about a month or two, worked with my sister and her husband.
They had a little store, and I helped them in the store.
But in 1920, I married my wife, Lena ,, who we had two kids.
We had a daughter in 1922 and a daughter, a son in 1925, who was Josephine .
Lampo Ruffino and my son, Johnny Lampo, runs the... runs the bakery, farmer's bakery here.
Farmer's bakery and a kolache shop.
Well, we go back a little further.
My daddy came to this country in 1984, in 1884.
He stayed in Louisiana about three years.
Three of my brothers and sisters were born in Louisiana, and then they moved to Texas.
And they crop-shared, farmed for a few years around until in 1902 then, we bought, like I said, we bought 300 acres of land.
So...
I was married three years and making a crop for myself.
I moved to Bryan, to the city of Bryan, and was, by the way, I was born just two and a half miles from the city limit of Bryan.
And I moved to Bryan and went to work for Lawrence Grocery Company, that $12 a week.
And I worked
for $12 a week for a period of about four or five years.
And eventually I got a big raise.
They raised me to $15.
It was a time at that time that depression was coming.
By that time, I was saving a little money out of that $12 a week on a raise of $15 because I spent it.
and didn't save any.
But time passed by, and my two kids were born, like I say, one in 1922 and one in 1925.
From then on, I worked for Lawrence Grocery Company, and later on I became a shipping clerk.
And then later on I became assistant manager and then manager of Lawrence Gross Company for a few years.
And finally Lawrence Gross Company sold out to Kimball and I went to back work for Kimball.
Well, after working for Kimball about a year and a half, I've always wanted to go into the retail business and I had accumulated a few dollars by that time.
Time got good after Roosevelt was elected and things began to get better.
And I bought Charlie Ball's store on 25th Street in Bryan.
And we stayed there for nine years and had good business.
As we were doing the Korean War, the Bryan Air Base was opened and we got a lot of business from the boys at Bryan Field.
somebody that may know what Bryan Field is, a blind training school, one of the first, I think, that was built.
And they had quite a few soldiers there and a little air corps, really.
And a lot of people from Bryan worked there.
But as time went on, we finally, in 1949, we thought that we'd
We had enough of the grocery business.
And so we stayed home.
We sold out.
And I actually retired.
And that was in 1958.
So after being retired about a year and a half, I was beginning to lose strength.
I didn't do anything but watch TV, and I decided I better go back to go to work and get a little exercise and nothing else.
And I went to work for Barney Morrow, who had a meatpacking and killing plan.
I just answered the telephone, and I take orders.
Finally got out of it, and it was the sale of my family.
From then on, about a year, I imagine,
And then my son Johnny bought the Easyway Drive-In, which is on 2612 Texas Avenue.
Now it's still the Easyway Drive-In, but in the meantime, we sold it to the U-Totem, and the lease was over.
They didn't renew the lease, so we had to take it back.
And my two grandkids, Johnny
Lampo and Frankie Lampo are on it now, and they are operating.
And, of course, it's a fabulous business.
In the meantime, my son had opened it, had built the building right next door to the drive-in, and built a place for the fish and chips.
And they stayed about a couple of years.
And of course, they went broke.
And we had to take the building.
And we made a bakery shop out of it, which is, we call it now, the Farmer's Bakery.
The Farmer's Bakery Shop, Kolache Inn.
And this is what we've done at the present time.
When we opened up the bakery shop, I worked, just helped them for a while, for about a year, and then retired again.
So I'm still retired.
You mentioned that you had gone to school in a one-room schoolhouse.
That's right.
What exactly was that like?
Well, it was just one-room school.
It taught all grades.
And we had one teacher who was a lady.
Her name was Mrs. Lloyd.
She was Mrs. Lloyd Smith at that time.
And now she would have passed away a few years ago.
And that one-room school, it was so bad that we never hardly used the door.
We went out through the windows and through the walls.
And in other words, it was just, it wasn't really a school.
It was just a barn.
But we learned a little bit.
And like I say that later after that, we moved to, they transferred us back to gospel school.
And they went...
They went to the seventh grade.
After the transfer, they transferred our land to the prospect school.
I went there two years.
And of course, like I say, I graduated from there.
And it was a one-room, it was a one-room school.
And they finally made a three-room school out of it.
They added a couple of rooms.
And it was a lot nicer school, a new school.
And we had two teachers.
We got quite a bit of experience and education out of it.
Like I said, we wanted to go from there.
We moved to Dallas and stayed a while and come back to Bryan and married.
What did you want to be when you were growing up?
I didn't know.
I didn't have any idea where to go except that I wanted to get out of the farm because there wasn't too much in it at the time.
We had sort of kind of a depression on and off there.
But this particular time, the best crop I ever made was in 1923 and it was the last.
So I sold out everything I had.
I had two mules and a horse and four or five cows and
all plowed too.
You needed them big.
You could buy them all for $100 probably now.
It takes $50,000 to start a farm now.
It's a lot different.
But no such thing as a tractor.
We did have a riding planter to plant that cotton with.
But that's about as far as mechanical that we got as a riding planter.
Was cotton the main crop?
Cotton was the main crop, yeah.
We raised a little corn, but not very much.
What happened when you moved to Dallas, when you moved off the farm?
When I moved to Dallas, I stayed with my sister and helped him in the store.
And my brother-in-law decided they'd move to California.
And then I came on back home.
By that time, I was about 19 or 20 years old.
On the 31st day of October, I married my wife.
That was October in 1920.
And we lived a happy life until 1965.
She passed away.
Since then, I've been living with my daughter.
What did you think of, was Dallas a big city?
Dallas was a big city then, yes.
At that time, we probably had
five or six thousand people in Bryan, maybe seven.
And of course Dallas probably had a couple hundred thousand.
Did you like it?
No, I never was too much for city life.
I used an open country to hunt rabbits, and actually that, for a long time, rabbits was our meat, wildlife was our meat, because we weren't able to buy it.
Of course in the holidays,
We would buy meat during the whole getting time.
We'd kill a hog and make a lard and put up bacon and sausage.
And the only thing that we had to buy was coffee and sugar and stuff that we couldn't raise.
We had chickens and turkeys and all kinds of eggs we needed.
What was the trip like going from here to Dallas?
Well, I went on a train.
I enjoyed that.
I still would enjoy a train ride now.
I was hoping that they'd put the soundtrack through here.
During the time that they had the railroad after my wife and I were married, I made a million trips to Dallas.
I have a brother.
I still have a brother there.
And he lost his wife also, by the way, within six months of my wife.
And he stayed with his daughter.
And I go to that business now once in a while, but I go on the bus.
It's not like riding that Sunday.
So I don't know too much of any experience that I might have had.
Have you ever been to Italy to see your father's parents?
No, I'm one of the few guys, I believe,
that in my younger days, I wanted to travel, but I never was able.
When I finally got able to travel, my health kind of broke down.
And I didn't want to get too far away from home.
But I never did have any desire of going back to Italy or any foreign country.
I have never set foot outside of the United States, never.
I've taken a few trips to California.
But I haven't.
We went to Memphis, Tennessee one time when my brother-in-law moved.
And between this time, he moved to Memphis, Tennessee.
At that time, Memphis had 17 lumber mills that made different things.
And we thought that my brother would have two grown brothers.
They could easily get a job there, so we all
We got our clothes and moved to Memphis.
We left in October, and it was warm here.
We left, of course, in our comfortable clothes.
But we had all our winter stuff, like quilts and blankets and stuff like that, packed in a truck.
And we shipped those by rail, by railroad.
Well, when we got off the train, there was about a foot's of snow in the streets of Memphis.
And boy, you talk about trees, and they're not frozen.
And it took us a month before we got our trunks closed, or I want to close them.
And at that time, I don't know whether many people remember the first gas I ever saw.
This is like Lone Star gas here.
The first gas I ever saw was in Memphis.
And we had to put a quarter in the meter.
according to two quarters or three quarters or four quarters.
And it would burn as long as that quarter lasted.
And when you run out, you're in the middle of a cooking meal, and you didn't have a quarter, you was out of luck.
So it was quite an experience.
We stayed there about a month.
And one of the experiences I had in Memphis during Christmas
At my age, say at that time I was around 12 years old, I had the measles.
And all I could do was look through the window and watch the streetcar come by.
And we stayed there 30 days and moved to Dallas.
When we moved to Dallas, we bought a grocery store.
Well, my two bold brothers came from the country, you know, and they saw them pretty girls in Dallas.
Well, they went kind of a little blind, you know.
And they left me and my father.
to run the store.
Well, he was well up in age by then.
And I went to school sometime in Dallas, too.
And we didn't stay that long enough to move.
But we were good.
And to be frank with you, we were losing money every day.
And we just sold out.
We had a fellow that won't buy it, and we sold it out before we went broke.
But my mother was a thrifty woman.
She always kept money away from us.
All of us.
We didn't know what she had.
And when we moved back in Bryan, we were my father and the rest of the family were worried how we were going to fight.
Our team back didn't know if we started farming.
In the meantime, we had rented our land for one year to one of the neighbors.
He was working there.
And he made 39 bales of cotton out here while we were in Dallas.
And we lost that.
And we had to come in and
We were just wondering where we were going to get the money to buy the team back and the wagon and everything.
My mother said, Joe, buy the mill.
I'll furnish the money.
She had $4,000.
No one knew she had.
She had saved all these years.
While we was still out in the country at home, we bought some property in town.
Of course, we...
I had that paid for when my daddy passed away in 1929.
And my mother passed away in 1945.
And they left us with a start to some of the inheritance that I had when I bought the store.
What was Brian like when you came back?
Brian was, before I moved to Brian,
I mean, into the city of Bryan.
The streets were just as muddy as you've ever seen in your life.
We sold people out in the country.
And they had boardwalks made out of two-by-twelve to walk across the street, no sidewalks or nothing.
It was a rough deal for a while.
And while I was working for Lawrence Roach Company, we had all these big farmers that they would hitch six mules to one wagon, maybe once a month.
They had commissaries out in the farm.
And we would load 2,000 pounds
different items on each wagon.
They'd come in six wagons, four, eight.
We'd put 2,000 pounds, 20,000, 20 bags of beans, 100 pounds, 20 sacks of potatoes.
In other words, 2,000 pounds to the load.
And they'd do that about once a year.
We had no, we had one little truck when I went to work, when I first came.
A little T-model Ford that you had to hand crank.
And that was the pain when the thing was hard to start.
Well, anyway, it wasn't long.
It wasn't too long before we got better trucks, and we went on.
And we were well financed when we sold out there.
The main man that had 51% of the stock, he thought everything would come through.
And he decided to sell it to Kimball.
and left a bunch of us without a job.
At that time, I was a salesman.
When the Depression came, I lost my manager's job.
I went to sell it.
I took the salesman's job.
They let about seven or eight boys go.
But I stayed gone one week.
They called me back.
They had too many going, and I had to go to work on just common labor.
Went back to $12 a week.
And from then on, of course, we arrived at $15 to $25.
Then NRA come in, if you remember that right.
You know, you don't remember, but you might have read about it.
Roy Lavelle come in.
He closed the bank before he got to his office in order to close all the banks.
And we never... Would it disturb you all to share all your books?
We'll be through in just a little bit.
We'll be through in just a little bit.
The NRA.
The NRA come in and they had to raise my salary.
We made pretty good money, and then it went on up, on up, started going up then.
About 1940, then World War II broke out.
You never had any desires to join the military?
I wasn't old enough.
See, in 1942, I was on the, when the war broke out,
I wasn't 18 yet.
But in November, not in November, but the end of World War II, I just had registered.
Wait a minute, let me get that straight.
In World War I, I just had registered.
And in August, and on the 11th, the armistice was signed, and they never did call me.
And then when World War II comes,
I was too old.
I was 42 years old.
I don't think anybody over 35.
So I missed both wars, and I regret it now, but I was glad then.
I don't know.
There's a lot of little things that happened to me during all this time.
It's hard to just think about them all at one time.
I had them.
I'll tell you this, though, that's what had happened in my family.
I had a sister who was born in Italy.
She was the only one that was born in Italy, and the rest of us were all born here.
And she married a widow with four kids.
I think it was five kids.
And she had five of her own.
And one day, she stroked off to the...
lake that for some reason or another one of the kids flipped in the air in this lake and she tried to save him and either one of them could swim.
I lost five nephews and nieces and she died also.
She was drowned also.
That was one of the greatest experiences of my life.
A sad experience.
It's one of the tragedies in the family.
And I had a little brother who was five years older than I that got killed by a mule and kicked him on the side.
But I didn't go to the doctor until he was dead.
He had to drive, take it two hours to get to town probably.
So that's one of the sad experiences for me.
Did you have any brothers that were in the military that were older than you?
Yes, I had a brother.
My oldest brother still living.
He's 87 years old now.
He wasn't married, and he was about 31 years old or something like that when he went to the service.
Then in the morning of the armistice, they had orders to go up to the front line.
Before they got to the front line,
with arms assigned, and he never hit the fire.
I didn't get the fire shot.
So he was pretty lucky then.
And it had hit him at service.
He was there about 11 months.
He was almost nine and a half years old.
And the other one is out and has a cataract in him.
But he gets along pretty good.
But he's 87 years old.
That's quite a few years, too, you know.
What did you think of California?
Well, I didn't go to California really for a good time.
I went mostly to visit my sister.
And she had two boys and a daughter.
And we just had a wonderful time.
We didn't go to any soap opera shows and stuff like that.
We had tickets to go to have a show.
I believe they called it Breakfast at Sardi or something like that.
I don't remember who it was.
James, I believe, was my commentary.
And we had tickets to go the next Monday morning, but I had to leave that Sunday because I had to be able to work the next Monday morning.
It was the first time I ever got on a plane, a four-motor plane.
The second time I went, we went in three, at least to call them, Astro Jet.
We had three motors, one on the tail and one on each wing.
We left Dallas at 10 o'clock and we arrived in Dallas at...
Ten on five.
Oh, the time change.
The time change, two hours.
We got that in two hours and five minutes.
And now, of course, they go faster than that now.
I mean, that was a little bit too fast, but you could tell it once you get where you can tell it.
I'd like to tell you a little bit about my father's life.
that he told us a lot about because I wasn't even born.
But he was born in 1852.
And of course, in Italy, they had compulsory military service then.
They always had it.
And when he was 21, he had to go into service.
And his father was dead.
His mother was living.
And he had a friend of his.
He didn't even know how to read and write.
He had a friend of his that used to write the letters for him, write to his mother.
So he told him one day, he said, John, if you want to write your mother from here on out, you'll have to do it yourself, because as long as I write for you, you'll never learn to read and write.
He knew the vowels and the alphabets, you know.
Of course, Italian language is, you read it.
You read it like it's written.
You don't have these silent letters in that.
Anyway, he learned to read and write.
And he belonged to an infantry.
And they would go on the movers.
And they'd have these shooting matches.
And my daddy got out of the Army six months ahead of time.
because he was a sharpshooter.
And his company, as long as he was in the Army, won the first prize.
And the major who was in charge of the company got to like him.
